Authors:
Dawson M White, Jen-Pan Huang, Orlando Adolfo Jara-Muñoz,
Santiago Madriñán, Richard H. Ree, Roberta J. Mason-Gamer
Title:
The Origins of Coca: Museum Genomics Reveals Multiple
Independent Domestications from Progenitor Erythroxylum gracilipes
Keywords:
Erythroxylum, Erythroxylaceae, Holocene, Museomics,
Neotropics, phylogeography, plant domestication, target-sequence
capture
Abstract:
Coca is a sacred and medicinal plant used by South
American Amerindians and mestizos and is the natural source of cocaine.
Even though the coca crop comprises four geographically separated
varieties classified into two species (Amazonian and Huánuco varieties
within Erythroxylum coca Lam., and Colombian and Trujillo varieties
within E. novogranatense (D.Morris) Hieron.), our current consensus is
that these developed from a single domestication event. In this study we
use genomic data from natural history collections to estimate the
geographic origins and genetic diversity of this economically and
culturally important crop. We found that the four varieties of coca
comprise two or three exclusive genetic lineages derived from the
widespread, wild relative E. gracilipes, and thus represent independent
origins of coca within South America. The identification of E.
gracilipes as progenitor and the finding of multiple domestications
frames a new and robust hypothesis of coca domestication that is
congruent with archaeological evidence. The Colombian and Trujillo coca
varieties are descended from a single, ancient domestication event in
northwestern South America. Huánuco coca was domesticated more recently,
possibly in southeastern Peru. Amazonian coca either shares a common
domesticated ancestor with Huánuco coca, or it was the product of a
third and most recent independent domestication event in the western
Amazon basin. This chronology of coca domestication reveals different
Holocene peoples in South America were able to independently transform
the same natural resource to serve their needs, in this case, a workaday
stimulant.
